content: And which party is the "Conservative" party? A Democrat from, say, Arizona would probably be more conservative than a Republican from New York. Most of the article is generalities and opinion that I disagree with. And yes, I read the entire article. But one paragraph in particular caught my eye; "Yet, the very same thing happened during the 1930s. The New Deal failed to end the Great Depression. The policy of appeasement embraced by Franklin Roosevelt emboldened Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan - paving the way to World War II." True, the New Deal did not end the Great Depression. But to claim FDR's policies during the late thirties were in any way responsible for WWII is simply wrong. If there was a pivitol moment during this time that led to war it occured in Munich in 1938. And the President WAS NOT THERE. In any case, it's impossible to imagine anything he could have done that would have prevented Hitler from invading Poland in 1939. What Roosevelt had to deal with was the extreeme level of isolationism in America during the 1930s. The "America First" group led by Charles Lindburg were very influential. Once he was re-elected in 1940 FDR began supplying arms to Brittan and France as well as rearming the nation. This Lend Lease program gave the defence industry a jump start.The 1940 naval rearmament bill he signed was responsuible for the Essex class carriers that did so much to bring victory in the Pacific.

content: “This is why, if the right truly seeks to capture national power, it must abandon its politics-only strategy. That is a road to defeat, decline and eventually, oblivion. It must engage the left on the cultural front, and seek to take back key institutions conservatives have surrendered - often without a fight. Liberals have been on offense for too long, setting the terms of debate. Conservatives must stop playing defense. They must be proactive, bold and courageous in crafting a long-term revolution. Conservatives didn't lose overnight. And they won't win overnight. The path to power lies not in Washington, but in New York and Los Angeles - and everywhere in between. It's the culture, stupid.” Turning to someone like Sarah Palin to stir up the culture war is the same as waiting for the Democrats to over reach – it is hope in place of a plan. Same sex marriage, gun control and immigration will stir up a loud, active constituency, but even the abortion issue is not going to bring conservatives to power in bad economic times. Republicans, under the guise of conservative leadership, were fiscally irresponsible when they held the purse strings from 1995 until 2007. President Bush betrayed just about every conservative ideal that there is while in office. http://forums.military.com/eve/forums/a/tpc/f/409192893...102001#1560028102001 Why should anyone trust the Republican Party with power, when they have no plan other than tax cuts and culture wars to lead the country? I believe that real conservative ideals are best for this country. But the disastrous eight years of President Bush’s leadership, along with stupid ideas like igniting a culture war will keep the Republicans and conservatives out of power for years to come.

content: We do not at this time have a conservative party, and I quite frankly wonder if such a beast is possible in American politics. The Republicans were long branded as the conservative party and fought the good fight for a while, but they wore out and we saw the evidence of that during the last election. The Republicans were both right and wrong, depending upon historical circumstances. They were right to assert that all men are created equal during the dark and bloody years of our Civil War, but they reneged on that by insisting on isolationism in the years leading up to WWII. 1964 was a watershed year for the Republicans both philosophically and politically. The Republican standard-bearer was Arizona governor Barry Goldwater, a principled man of highly impeccable conservative standards. But historically we were not ready for such a man or his message at that time. One must keep in mind that by the mid 1960s the civil rights movement was reaching a critical tipping point--the majority of Americans were ready to reject the decades-old framework of Jim Crow and integrate black Americans into general society. The question was how would this be done? Harry Truman, a Democrat, took the first step by integrating the armed forces in 1949. In 1950 a black American could command a company of soldiers in places like Korea but could not go and sit with those soldiers for dinner in places like Richmond. This was insanity, and most Americans recognized it as such. By 1964 it was clear that Jim Crow segregation was no longer viable and that black Americans needed to be given entry to all aspects of American life. LBJ sought to do just that through the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Not so fast, said Goldwater--this is not the responsibility of the federal government but of the states. Goldwater was technically right but at the time politically wrong--he went down in defeat and was tarred by association with all kinds of kooks from Birchers to Klansmen, never mind that the latter were overwhelmingly Democratic. The 1960s and 1970s were the "wilderness years" for the GOP, and this was for good reason. When Moses led the Israelites out of Egyptian bondage he faced a generational period--forty years--of wandering in a hostile wilderness and learning to survive in that wilderness. The Israelites had to learn, by necessity, to stop being slaves and to live or die by their own means. The Republicans had their Moses too, but it's unclear who that Moses was. In strictly political terms it seems that Moses was Richard Nixon, the man who coopted Southern Democrats and led the party to an electoral victory. But philosophically the Republicans had to wait a few decades. The Republican Party's real Moses was Ronald Regan. He was a man who fundamentally understood conservatism and how it benefitted both individual Americans and America as a nation. It's perhaps fitting that as a young man I despised Regan but I now appreciate him and what he did for this country. He stood tall and firm and forced a truely evil empire to admit defeat. And he did so without unnecessarily shedding the blood of American soldiers. And I was one of those soldiers. Reagan was an optimist and an orator and a leader the likes of which we have not seen since FDR, never mind the fact that politically Reagan was FDR's polar opposite. Regan gave conservatism a popular face and clear principles. Republicans since then have squandered them, and we now see the result. We at this point do not have a conservative party--the Republicans are so enamored of "bipartisanship" that they will sell each and every one of us down the river to score points with the Democrats. That was McCain's fatal flaw. It's time for us to break from the Republican Party and to accept the demise of that party. A new one will arise in its place. That's pretty much the nature of America--we're optimists....

content: Anybody who ever believed Bush was a conservative is in need of a SERIOUS reality check!!!! His father was not a conservative and neither was he!! His new tone in Washington set the stage for total failure in that he would not confront any one would NOT use the veto except when it didn't matter and gave away the store when it came to spending!! The party fell apart under his watch because there was no clear leadership and still isn't!! When people run on clear conservative principles they win...period!! When they try and be all things to all people they lose....period!! The guy who we call president now, is a classical example of triangulation in politics and every one needs to look at the example he gave to win. content: And which party is the "Conservative" party? A Democrat from, say, Arizona would probably be more conservative than a Republican from New York. Most of the article is generalities and opinion that I disagree with. And yes, I read the entire article. But one paragraph in particular caught my eye; "Yet, the very same thing happened during the 1930s. The New Deal failed to end the Great Depression. The policy of appeasement embraced by Franklin Roosevelt emboldened Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan - paving the way to World War II." True, the New Deal did not end the Great Depression. But to claim FDR's policies during the late thirties were in any way responsible for WWII is simply wrong. If there was a pivitol moment during this time that led to war it occured in Munich in 1938. And the President WAS NOT THERE. In any case, it's impossible to imagine anything he could have done that would have prevented Hitler from invading Poland in 1939. What Roosevelt had to deal with was the extreeme level of isolationism in America during the 1930s. The "America First" group led by Charles Lindburg were very influential. Once he was re-elected in 1940 FDR began supplying arms to Brittan and France as well as rearming the nation. This Lend Lease program gave the defence industry a jump start.The 1940 naval rearmament bill he signed was responsuible for the Essex class carriers that did so much to bring victory in the Pacific.

content: We do not at this time have a conservative party, and I quite frankly wonder if such a beast is possible in American politics. The Republicans were long branded as the conservative party and fought the good fight for a while, but they wore out and we saw the evidence of that during the last election. The Republicans were both right and wrong, depending upon historical circumstances. They were right to assert that all men are created equal during the dark and bloody years of our Civil War, but they reneged on that by insisting on isolationism in the years leading up to WWII. 1964 was a watershed year for the Republicans both philosophically and politically. The Republican standard-bearer was Arizona governor Barry Goldwater, a principled man of highly impeccable conservative standards. But historically we were not ready for such a man or his message at that time. One must keep in mind that by the mid 1960s the civil rights movement was reaching a critical tipping point--the majority of Americans were ready to reject the decades-old framework of Jim Crow and integrate black Americans into general society. The question was how would this be done? Harry Truman, a Democrat, took the first step by integrating the armed forces in 1949. In 1950 a black American could command a company of soldiers in places like Korea but could not go and sit with those soldiers for dinner in places like Richmond. This was insanity, and most Americans recognized it as such. By 1964 it was clear that Jim Crow segregation was no longer viable and that black Americans needed to be given entry to all aspects of American life. LBJ sought to do just that through the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Not so fast, said Goldwater--this is not the responsibility of the federal government but of the states. Goldwater was technically right but at the time politically wrong--he went down in defeat and was tarred by association with all kinds of kooks from Birchers to Klansmen, never mind that the latter were overwhelmingly Democratic. The 1960s and 1970s were the "wilderness years" for the GOP, and this was for good reason. When Moses led the Israelites out of Egyptian bondage he faced a generational period--forty years--of wandering in a hostile wilderness and learning to survive in that wilderness. The Israelites had to learn, by necessity, to stop being slaves and to live or die by their own means. The Republicans had their Moses too, but it's unclear who that Moses was. In strictly political terms it seems that Moses was Richard Nixon, the man who coopted Southern Democrats and led the party to an electoral victory. But philosophically the Republicans had to wait a few decades. The Republican Party's real Moses was Ronald Regan. He was a man who fundamentally understood conservatism and how it benefitted both individual Americans and America as a nation. It's perhaps fitting that as a young man I despised Regan but I now appreciate him and what he did for this country. He stood tall and firm and forced a truely evil empire to admit defeat. And he did so without unnecessarily shedding the blood of American soldiers. And I was one of those soldiers. Reagan was an optimist and an orator and a leader the likes of which we have not seen since FDR, never mind the fact that politically Reagan was FDR's polar opposite. Regan gave conservatism a popular face and clear principles. Republicans since then have squandered them, and we now see the result. We at this point do not have a conservative party--the Republicans are so enamored of "bipartisanship" that they will sell each and every one of us down the river to score points with the Democrats. That was McCain's fatal flaw. It's time for us to break from the Republican Party and to accept the demise of that party. A new one will arise in its place. That's pretty much the nature of America--we're optimists....
reply: We do not at this time have a conservative party, and I quite frankly wonder if such a beast is possible in American politics. The Republicans were long branded as the conservative party and fought the good fight for a while, but they wore out and we saw the evidence of that during the last election. The Republicans were both right and wrong, depending upon historical circumstances. They were right to assert that all men are created equal during the dark and bloody years of our Civil War, but they reneged on that by insisting on isolationism in the years leading up to WWII. 1964 was a watershed year for the Republicans both philosophically and politically. The Republican standard-bearer was Arizona governor Barry Goldwater, a principled man of highly impeccable conservative standards. But historically we were not ready for such a man or his message at that time. One must keep in mind that by the mid 1960s the civil rights movement was reaching a critical tipping point--the majority of Americans were ready to reject the decades-old framework of Jim Crow and integrate black Americans into general society. The question was how would this be done? Harry Truman, a Democrat, took the first step by integrating the armed forces in 1949. In 1950 a black American could command a company of soldiers in places like Korea but could not go and sit with those soldiers for dinner in places like Richmond. This was insanity, and most Americans recognized it as such. By 1964 it was clear that Jim Crow segregation was no longer viable and that black Americans needed to be given entry to all aspects of American life. LBJ sought to do just that through the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Not so fast, said Goldwater--this is not the responsibility of the federal government but of the states. Goldwater was technically right but at the time politically wrong--he went down in defeat and was tarred by association with all kinds of kooks from Birchers to Klansmen, never mind that the latter were overwhelmingly Democratic. The 1960s and 1970s were the "wilderness years" for the GOP, and this was for good reason. When Moses led the Israelites out of Egyptian bondage he faced a generational period--forty years--of wandering in a hostile wilderness and learning to survive in that wilderness. The Israelites had to learn, by necessity, to stop being slaves and to live or die by their own means. The Republicans had their Moses too, but it's unclear who that Moses was. In strictly political terms it seems that Moses was Richard Nixon, the man who coopted Southern Democrats and led the party to an electoral victory. He was a man who fundamentally understood conservatism and how it benefitted both individual Americans and America as a nation. It's perhaps fitting that as a young man I despised Regan but I now appreciate him and what he did for this country. He stood tall and firm and forced a truely evil empire to admit defeat.
